bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 9, 1890

div1.p: Lazear writes that he is nearly finished with his courses.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 9, 1890
div1.p:
The worst of the
examinations came off yesterday and
I am now through all except one on
the arm which had been held before
we got here. We are to have a
special examination on that, on
next Friday. I feel now that the
rest is over and I am taking things
more easy and looking around
more. I went to an operation this
morning by Prof. Chiene. And this afternoon
I saw two post-mortems. I am
still dissecting but I think I
shall finish it up this week.

I finally succeeded in finding
Mrs. Hailman on Saturday night.
She was accompanied by George,
Miss Hays and Miss Haring Waring.
She had been in Edinburgh for several
days, and while here she received
a letter from you saying that
I was here. It was rather odd
that she got it while in Edinburgh.

I took them around a little
on Sunday afternoon and showed
them some of the sights which they
had not yet seen, and dined
with them on Sunday evening.
Mrs. Hailman sent her love to
you and says she will write soon.
She is looking very well as is
also Miss Hays, Miss Waring who
was with them is a very nice
young girl. They went from here
to York and will continue
on to London and then they
will make a trip to Switzerland.
They will return to America
in September.

I went to St. Giles Cathedral on
Sunday and I was rather surprised
at the Amount of Ceremony they
went through. It is Presbyterian you
know but they had robes, liturgy
and everything.

Last night I heard a man playing
the harp on the street and it was
one of the finest things I ever
heard. He played a number of
old Scoth and Irish airs, Tom
Moore's songs. I wished that
you could hear him as I
know you would have
enjoyed it.

I was sorry to learn by your
letter of the 26th of June that your
room was so hot. You must
not stay there if you are
uncomfortable. You had better
go th to the mountains for a few
weeks and then go to Uncle
Toms.

I will look around in London
at some of the old furniture and
I will also find what the
duty will be. I have not
seen any of the pebble breast-
pins here, but I will look
around for them.

I hope we shall succeed in
doing better than Mrs. Denison's.
However if we cannot we will
have to go there again. We might
be able to make some special
arrangement so as to get good
pieces of f beef. I have no doubt
that by judicious feeing we
could manage to get the best
cut every time. We used to
have to put up with miserable
fag ends last year whenever
we were late.
